description.what: HyperText Markup Language (HTML) is the main markup language for creating web pages and other information that can be displayed in a web browser.
description.why: HTML is a core technology in creating web pages - you won't get far without it!

description.what: Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) is a style sheet language used for describing the presentation semantics (the look and formatting) of a document written in a markup language.
description.why: Nobody likes looking at unstyled pages. Use CSS to improve the look and feel of your web pages.

description.what: JavaScript (JS) is a programming language that can be understood by web browsers.
description.why: Using JS makes your web pages or applications dynamic and interactive.

description.what: jQuery is a JavaScript library that makes building web applications significantly easier.
description.why: Using jQuery provides abstractions that will reduce the learning curve and allow you to start building your ideas, faster.

description.what: Backbone.js is an MV* framework that gives structure to web applications.
description.why: Larger applications need structure as they grow in complexity. Backbone provides one of the most popular current solutions to this problem.

description.what: SASS is an extension of CSS3, adding nested rules, variables, mixins, selector inheritance and more.
description.why: SASS provides additional features that can improve the modularity, maintainability and reusability of your CSS code, among other benefits.

description.what: LESS extends CSS with dynamic behavior such as variables, mixins, operations and functions.
description.why: Similar benefits to SASS, albeit some say LESS is simpler and easier to use.

description.what: RequireJS is a JavaScript file and module loader.
description.why: RequireJS encapsulates your code into modules and prevents you from having to manually define script dependancies.
